postsData.name:
Dan Goodman
Dan Goodman
postsData.content:
When your company is struggling, don‚Äôt be accommodating.

Don‚Äôt make financial sacrifices against yourself for your employer.

Don‚Äôt‚Ä¶
 take a pay cut
 delay commission payout
 convert part of base salary to bonus
 take equity in lieu of base salary
 allow last year‚Äôs commission to become next year‚Äôs pay increase

If you do, you‚Äôll regret it when they terminate you down the road.

Especially when the equity you received in lieu of salary never vests or is not worth anything.

Especially when the bonus you agreed to for giving up some base salary is never paid out because you‚Äôve been let go before the payment date.

Especially if they don‚Äôt fulfill their promises and replace you and discard you when they‚Äôre done with you.

Value your time. Make sure you get paid for it.

comments.commentText: Dan Goodman It's like they say, 'Put your own oxygen mask on first!'

postsData.commentAdded: Wise advice! Its crucial to prioritize your financial well-being and not lose sight of your worth in challenging times. #KnowYourValue

postsData.name:
Fatou Seck Mathon
Fatou Seck Mathon
postsData.content:
Losing your job doesn‚Äôt make you worthless. 

A layoff, a toxic workplace, or a big failure shakes your self-confidence.

You question yourself, doubting your abilities and feeling stuck.

I have been there.

But confidence isn't something you wait to feel again.

Take these actions to rebuild it, one step at a time.

 Reframe the setback.
‚Ü≥ This wasn't the end of your story; it's part of your growth.
‚Ü≥ Write down 3 lessons you've learned from this experience.

 Change the narrative in your head.
‚Ü≥ Catch yourself when self-doubt creeps in.
‚Ü≥ Replace negative with positive self-talk.

 Reconnect with what makes you feel strong.
‚Ü≥ What activity used to bring you joy? Start doing it again.
‚Ü≥ Small wins build momentum; celebrate them.

 Surround yourself with the right people.
‚Ü≥ Spend time with those who uplift you.
‚Ü≥ Distance yourself from those who feed your doubts.

 Take action before you feel ready.
‚Ü≥ Confidence follows action, not the other way around.
‚Ü≥ Start small, send that email, make that call, and take that step.

Confidence isn't about never falling.

It's about knowing you can rise again.

What's one thing you do daily to protect your self-confidence?

Repost to help someone rebuild their confidence.
Followfor more.

comments.commentText: Love this Fatou Seck. Losing a job is just a detour in the path to your next chapter.
comments.userName: Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor

postsData.commentAdded: Such an uplifting reminder! Rebuilding confidence is a journey, and these actionable steps can make all the difference. Thank you for sharing!

Here‚Äôs a quick recap of what‚Äôs been happening in the space and how we move forward:

‚Äî DeepSeek‚Äôs AI breakthrough: Development costs under $6 million, significantly lower than OpenAI‚Äôs billion-dollar investments. Unlike OpenAI, DeepSeek offers open-source solutions for more customization, providing a cost-effective and energy-efficient alternative to Western AI giants.

Its launch caused a notable decline in Nvidia‚Äôs stock price.

‚Äî OpenAI, in collaboration with Oracle, SoftBank, and MGX, announced ‚ÄúThe Stargate Project‚Äù to build an AI infrastructure system with the U.S. government.

‚Äî Mark Zuckerberg revealed that Meta plans to invest $60-65 billion in AI initiatives in 2025.

As we can see, much investing is happening and DeepSeek‚Äôs success proved that innovation can break through, and I believe more startups will gain traction and adoption because of it.

Startups aren‚Äôt just competing with giants anymore, they‚Äôre surpassing them‚Ä¶

For those of us building, this is our chance to create something truly valuable. It‚Äôs easy to feel overwhelmed with new AI projects launching daily, but real breakthroughs are still ahead‚Äîespecially for Vacabee and the AI potential we‚Äôre unlocking.

I‚Äôm grateful to be part of this space, pushing Web3 and AI forward with real innovation. But to succeed, we must build sustainably, with purpose‚Äîno shortcuts.

The future is being built now.

postsData.name:
Ryan R. Sullivan
Ryan R. Sullivan
postsData.content:
If you (or your marketer) are posting videos on LinkedIn, you're wasting a ton of time. 

Here's why:

1. You record phone/webcam videos.
2. You post them.
3. They last 2-3 days.
4. You record more.
5. Repeat.

The problem? ‚Üí Those videos disappear.

LinkedIn‚Äôs feed pushes posts for a week ùò¢ùòµ ùò£ùò¶ùò¥ùòµ.

Podcasting is the opposite:

 My 2018 podcast episode still gets downloads.
 My 2012 YouTube video gets 10,000 views/year.
 10% of my client‚Äôs new listeners start with episode 1‚Äî*three years later*.

ùó¶ùó≤ùó≤ ùòÅùóµùó≤ ùó±ùó∂ùó≥ùó≥ùó≤ùóøùó≤ùóªùó∞ùó≤?

If you‚Äôre just posting, keep posting.

If you‚Äôre marketing, rethink your strategy.

If it can‚Äôt rank on Google, it‚Äôs not worth the effort.

Stay strategized, my friends.

all platforms have their woes i guess!

postsData.name:
Adam Graham
Adam Graham
postsData.content:
Feeling exhausted even after 8+ hours of sleep?

You‚Äôre not alone.

Many of us think rest only means getting more sleep.
Yes, sleep is important.

Bryan Johnson said, "Sleep is a lighthouse that can't be negotiated away, wished aside, or overrun."

But this doesn‚Äôt only apply to sleep, it applies to all forms of rest.

I was reading the book Sacred Rest by Dr Dalton-Smith,
and she pointed out something important.

There are 7 types of rest to fully recharge:

1. Physical Rest
Your body needs recovery to heal and restore energy.

- Go to bed 30 minutes earlier each night.
- Do gentle stretches or yoga before bed.

2. Mental Rest
Your mind needs breaks to stay clear and focused.

- Take short breaks every hour to reset your mind.
- Write down racing thoughts before bed.

3. Emotional Rest
Bottled-up feelings drain your energy.

- Set boundaries and say ‚Äúno‚Äù when needed.
- Talk openly with a trusted friend or therapist.

4. Social Rest
Not all social interactions are energising.

- Spend time with people who uplift you.
- Take a break from draining social interactions.

5. Creative Rest
Your mind needs inspiration to stay creative.

- Take a walk in nature and observe your surroundings.
- Listen to music that inspires you.

6. Sensory Rest
Constant noise and screens overwhelm your senses.

- Turn off notifications for an hour each day.
- Spend 10 minutes in silence before going to bed.

7. Spiritual Rest
You need to feel connected to something bigger than yourself.

- Spend a few minutes each day meditating or praying.
- Reflect on your values and purpose through writing in a journal.

Burnout isn‚Äôt always about doing too much.

Sometimes, it‚Äôs about not resting in the right way.

Which type of rest do you need most today?

* * * * * * *

If you liked this post, you may like my newsletter: The Growth Mindset.



Repost this to help your network & follow mefor more content like this.

comments.commentText: Feeling exhausted despite getting enough sleep is often a sign that your body needs more than just rest it needs restoration. True recovery comes from balancing all seven types of rest, not just physical sleep. Mental clarity, emotional boundaries, social balance, and creative inspiration all play a role in keeping energy levels high. Burnout isn‚Äôt just from overworking; it‚Äôs often from neglecting the right kind of rest.
It‚Äôs the combination of mental clarity, emotional boundaries, and creative inspiration that creates lasting energy.

It‚Äôs easy to assume more sleep will solve everything, but true rest goes so much deeper.
Mental Health :) Exactly. Rest that goes deeper than sleep is what truly restores us.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights on the different forms of rest! Its essential to recognize that true recharging goes beyond just sleep. What‚Äôs your go-to method for recharging?

postsData.name:
Justin Welsh
Justin Welsh
postsData.content:
Most people quit too early.

Successful entrepreneurs don't.

‚Ä¢ They work through the hard days
‚Ä¢ They build through uncertainty
‚Ä¢ They solve problems others avoid
‚Ä¢ They embrace discomfort daily

Not because they're special.
Not because they have better ideas.

But because they understand how this game works.

Success isn't about talent.
It's about tolerance.
It's about resilience.

The people who win aren't always the smartest.

They're the ones still standing after everyone else walked away.

If you want to learn how to build a business online, check out The Creator MBA.

It's not just another course - it's a complete system for those willing to do the hard work of building a sustainable business.

Inside, you'll discover:

‚Ä¢ Step-by-step systems for growth
‚Ä¢ Real strategies I've used to build income
‚Ä¢ How to turn your knowledge into products
‚Ä¢ My exact process for running everything myself

5,000+ entrepreneurs have already joined.

Ready to start your business journey?

Learn more:

comments.commentText: Side note: If you want to be really, really good at something, commit to doing it for one year. If you can do the same thing, every single day, for 365 days in a row, it's hard to not get exceptionally better at it.

Justin Welsh one of our team core commitments is ‚Äúbe here a year from now‚Äù 
For the same principle you described.

I almost gave up on my financial planning practice after 3 months of making almost no money.

I remember thinking "maybe this just isn't for me."

But looking back, that struggle was the best thing that could've happened.

It taught me that success isn't about talent (I definitely didn't have any starting out )

It's about showing up when it feels impossible.

Almost everyone who "failed" in this industry didn't actually fail.

They just stopped trying before success could catch up to them.

90% of advisors fail in the first 3 years, but the 10% who make it?

We're just the ones who refused to quit.

Now 5 years in, I couldn't imagine doing anything else.
Wow..what a journey. Thanks for sharing, Mando.
Justin Welsh thanks a ton brother!

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Resilience truly is the cornerstone of entrepreneurial success. Excited to see how The Creator MBA can empower others to build sustainably!

postsData.name:
Tomasz Boinski
Tomasz Boinski
postsData.content:
Something big is happening on LinkedIn  
hashtag
#SocialSaturday 

It‚Äôs not just about posting updates or connecting with colleagues anymore. The platform is changing fast. By 2025, LinkedIn won‚Äôt just be a place where professionals network; it‚Äôll be a place where people come to watch, learn, and engage in a way we haven‚Äôt seen before.

Video is becoming the heartbeat of LinkedIn. Not just as another content format, but as a new way for people to consume information. It‚Äôs not about reading long posts and scrolling past static images anymore, LinkedIn wants you to stop, watch, and stay. Imagine a
where you go, not just to check in, but to actually watch something valuable, just like you would on
or
. That‚Äôs where we‚Äôre headed.

And it‚Äôs not just how we consume content, it‚Äôs how we create it, too. The time between having a great idea and getting it out into the world? It‚Äôs getting shorter. No more endless edits, no more second-guessing. The best content is the one that feels real, and LinkedIn is making space for more authenticity, more fast-moving ideas, and less over-polished fluff.

Not all creators are the same.
Some share insights based on their own expertise. Others stick to safe, templated content; infographics, carousels, things that ‚Äúperform well.‚Äù But real impact? That comes from honest, experience-driven content, even if the engagement numbers fluctuate. That‚Äôs where trust is built. That‚Äôs where credibility grows.

We‚Äôre also seeing a shift in who gets to be the voice of a company. It‚Äôs no longer just about the CEO or founder. More and more, companies are looking within their teams, building multiple personal brands that work together, creating a bigger, more authentic voice across the platform. Because people trust people more than they trust companies.

One of the biggest changes?
LinkedIn is moving away from polished, structured posts and towards something more human. Less robotic. Less corporate-sounding. More like a real person talking. And that means standing out isn‚Äôt about following trends, it‚Äôs about creating your own.

? They‚Äôre not just a passing trend. They‚Äôre becoming key players in how companies connect with audiences. Businesses are realizing that tapping into creator communities isn‚Äôt just ‚Äúmarketing‚Äù; it‚Äôs building real relationships.

At the end of the day, LinkedIn in 2025 won‚Äôt be about chasing engagement. It‚Äôll be about trust. About sharing what really matters. About solving problems instead of just performing well.

And honestly? I‚Äôm here for it.
I will add my brick to the LinkedIn legacy with, as it is a gateway to safe and secure networking  via LinkedIn! Yes!is integrated with LinkedIn, providing unique synergies between features for a better networking experience!

If you‚Äôve noticed these shifts too, drop your thoughts below. Let‚Äôs talk about what‚Äôs coming.

postsData.name:
Devroop Saha
Devroop Saha
postsData.content:
I was just bored, that's why I decided to dive deep into the concept of prompt jailbreaking from a probabilistic lens.

It's hard to imagine how a seemingly 'non mathematical' concept can be this much mathematical.

I tried to correlate the probabilistic nature of token generation with prompt jailbreaking. Jailbreaking is essentially the method to manipulate prompts in such a way that will persuade the LLM to generate 'unsafe' and 'harmful' content. So if we view this from a token generation POV, we can say that it is basically an optimization problem. Here, we essentially want to MAXIMIZE the probability of generating 'harmful' tokens based on the input prompts.

So, this is how the very definition of jailbreaking makes sense. We are essentially trying to manipulate our input prompts in such a way (setting up inputs) such that it WILL GENERATE Harmful content (probability of harmful token generation is maximised).

Here is my full mathematical analysis of the jailbreaking concept and how it can be converted into an optimization problem.

Hope you find it bit insightful: ). I will share more mathematical concepts like this.

comments.commentText: Very informative

postsData.commentAdded: Fascinating take on prompt jailbreaking! Its intriguing to see how mathematical principles can explain such complex behavior in LLMs. Looking forward to more!

Managing B2B accounts is no longer just about relationships.
It‚Äôs about data, automation, and seamless collaboration.

1. CRM: The Heart of Account Management

2. Account-Based Marketing (ABM) Tools

3. Customer Success & Retention

4. Communication & Collaboration

5. Data & Analytics for Decision-Making

postsData.name:
Claude G. Th√©oret
Claude G. Th√©oret
postsData.content:
If you follow me on Twitter you know that I have been posting about DeepSeek. 
Ultimately the DeepSeek success is a story of elegance out of constraints versus brute force.
DeepSeek's success reminds me of a few key points of my career as an Astrophyscist and then as an early AI entrepreneur.

Constraints on compute always happen, and they almost always lead to smarter ways of doing large projects. In academia and in my frist startup, we were constrained by compute. When everyone went to the cloud, we created our own cloud, we cute massively from floats to integers when we could, we used hashtables, we would even use pointers where possible. This drastically reduced memory needs and cost.

We also used the 5% rule: if a result used less ressources but acheived the same result to 5% accuracy we would use the solution with drastically lower ressources.



------
Imagine cutting-edge AI that doesn‚Äôt require massive data centers or a billion-dollar budget. That‚Äôs exactly what DeepSeek is delivering with its groundbreaking approach. Here's why this could be a major inflection point for AI development:

Using less memory:

Traditional AI is like writing every number with 32 decimal places. DeepSeek was like used 8, still accurate enough with a whopping - 75% less memory needed.

 The Multi-Token System
DeepSeek reads entire phrases instead of single words‚Äîmaking it 2x faster and nearly as accurate. When processing billions of words, this efficiency is a game-changer.
 Expert Systems at Work
Unlike traditional models (where all parameters are always active), DeepSeek uses an expert system. Only the relevant "experts" wake up for the task at hand. This results in:
 95% lower API costs
 Training cost down from $100M ‚Üí $5M
 Hardware requirement: Just 2,000 GPUs instead of 100,000
Ô∏è Open Source Transparency
Here‚Äôs the twist: DeepSeek made it all open source! The code, technical papers, and methods are accessible to everyone, making it clear this isn‚Äôt magic‚Äîjust brilliant engineering.
 Why This Matters
1Ô∏è‚É£ AI development is now more accessible than ever.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Big Tech's advantage? It‚Äôs shrinking.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Nvidia‚Äôs hardware dominance could face serious disruption.
 The Takeaway
DeepSeek‚Äôs innovative approach‚Äîbuilding smarter, not bigger‚Äîmay be the beginning of a new era in AI. This feels like the shift from mainframes to PCs or the rise of cloud computing.
 What do you think? Is this the future of AI? Let‚Äôs discuss the implications!

postsData.name:
Jen Blandos
Jen Blandos
postsData.content:
You‚Äôre not stuck.

You‚Äôre just scared to move.

And that fear is keeping you exactly where you are.

A friend once told me, "You're lucky you got out."

But luck had nothing to do with it.

Many years ago, I packed my bags, put my dog on a plane, and moved to a country I had only dreamed of living in. My friends and family thought I was crazy. While others had stability, I had a mattress on the floor, pot noodles for dinner, and a minimum-wage job.

It wasn‚Äôt glamorous. It wasn‚Äôt easy.

But doing something different - taking the risk - was the only way forward.

Everything is a choice.

Sometimes it works. Sometimes it doesn‚Äôt.

But if you never take the leap, you‚Äôll never know what you‚Äôre truly capable of.

If I hadn‚Äôt stepped onto that plane to Brussels in 1998, my life would look very different today. That risk, the struggles, the discomfort - those are what pushed me to the next level.

What about you? Have you ever taken a risk that changed your life?

Or is something still holding you back from making the move?

 Know someone on the edge of a big decision?
Send this their way - sometimes, all we need is a little push.
 Image by @theopeninvite - because sometimes, a simple reminder is all we need.

comments.commentText: We don‚Äôt have to wait for permission to take a leap into the unknown; that‚Äôs where real growth happens Jen Blandos.
comments.userName: Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor

postsData.commentAdded: Inspiring words! Taking risks often leads to the most rewarding experiences. Heres to embracing discomfort and unlocking our true potential! üåü

postsData.content:
People overcomplicate being a virtual assistant
(Ditch these common mistakes)

Ô∏è Avoid being a generalist, trying to be everywhere with your content.

Ô∏è Avoid using industry terms without any context.

Ô∏è Avoid writing clich√©s and generic content.

Ô∏è Avoid cold pitching without prior engagement or research.

Do This Instead:

Ô∏è Identify a niche you want to specialize in: It doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre limited, but be known as a specific VA first.

Ô∏è Find top VA creators on LinkedIn to learn from: like,,,.

Depending on the niche you want.

Ô∏è Understand the power of networking: engage with other VAs in your feed, share value, and leave thoughtful comments.

Ô∏è Research your ICPs (Ideal Client Profiles).

Take time to understand their struggles, what keeps them up at night, and focus on solving one problem at a time.

It takes a lot of work and intentionality.

I‚Äôm rooting for you.

As a service provider, what is your go-to skill?




_______________
